title: Gerardus Mercator
summary: Gerardus Mercator (/dʒɪˈrɑːrdəs mɜːrˈkeɪtər/;[lower-alpha 1][lower-alpha 2][lower-alpha 3] 5 March 1512 – 2 December 1594)[lower-alpha 4] was a 16th-century geographer, cosmographer and cartographer from the County of Flanders. He is most renowned for creating the 1569 world map based on a new projection which represented sailing courses of constant bearing (rhumb lines) as straight lines—an innovation that is still employed in nautical charts.
